data.title: Enabling setting 'Use Custom Title Bar' prevents double click on title bar from maximizing window
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

When the 'Use Custom Title Bar' setting is enabled, double clicking on the title bar doesn't enlarge the window on OS X Yosemite
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Enable Settings->Core->'Use Custom Title Bar' setting
2. Restart Atom for setting to take effect
3. Double click the title bar

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
The window should enlarge to fill the screen

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
No effect.
### Versions

Atom: 1.11.1
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome: 49.0.2623.75
Node: 5.10.0
OS X Yosemite 10.10.5

data.title: Can't read "large" files
data.body:
### Description

The editor consistently crashes while loading files larger than 3MB.

I am suspecting this has to do with the way the file is loaded or all of the different modules applied to it, resulting in rather large data sets and/or operations.

I would suggest that if a larger file is detected, it either switch to using a streaming file load and only loading what is currently seen or that automatic markup/module runs and what not are automatically disabled for large files.

3MB is a rough estimate of about 3-4000 lines of code, so this would also essentially cause trouble with writing larger blocks of code or larger libraries.
### Steps to Reproduce

Load a file larger than 3MB

**Expected behavior:** Open the file for viewing

**Actual behavior:** Editor hangs or crashs
### Versions

1.10.2

data.title: Remember syntax for opened files or improve auto detect
data.body:
Perl and Prolog annoyingly share the `.pl` extension. This ambivalence throws Atom into a dilemma when auto-detecting the syntax of a file. I often use Prolog and Perl files at the same time or interchangeably and more often then not files get opened with the wrong syntax highlighting. When opening a file for the first time, that is not an issue: Atom tried to detect the correct syntax, and perhaps it failed - but I can always manually switch to the correct syntax. The problem is that this issue recurs every single time I open a `.pl` file. What I mean is, if for `file-a.pl` Atom guessed Prolog and I change the syntax to Perl, then close the file, and open it again, Atom will - again - guess Prolog. I guess you understand my frustration.

As I see it there are at least two ways to solve this issue:
### 1. Remember the syntax per file

As soon as you open `file-a.pl` Atom could write to a CFG file somewhere that `path/to/file-a.pl` is auto-detected as Prolog. If the user then changes the syntax to Perl, the changes would be made in the CFG file as well. When closing and re-opening the file, Atom would check the CFG file to see if an entry with that file name is present and use the given syntax.

The downside is that if you are working with a lot of files, this CFG file can grow significantly. Therefore it might be useful to have a check of the CFG at Atom start-up where entries older than e.g. a week are removed from the file, or that the oldest entries are removed when the CFG file reaches a size of > X KB.
### 2. Improve auto-detection

This might be the easiest to implement, though I cannot find it in the source after briefly glancing. (I don't have a lot of time, and when I couldn't find it I wrote this post.) In this particular case, it should be easy to distinguish Perl. Often it's right there in the first line:

`#!/usr/bin/perl`

But doing a regex check on the first line for this specific issue should only be a quick fix. I like the first idea more.

data.title: Atom 1.12-Beta1 :atom.project.relativizePath behaviour changed.
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

In versions 1.11 and prior a call to atom.project.relativizePath would result in an array with array[0] being the project path and array[1] being the relative file path.

In version 1.12-beta1 the call returns array[0] null and array[1] the full path/filename. No project path
### Steps to Reproduce

Given a file that exists inside a project call `atom.projectRelativizePath(filename)`

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2313237/19344481/469e1456-9132-11e6-9ffc-c22a3aa096e1.png)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2313237/19344233/459e487e-9131-11e6-9d21-58a22fe2cee7.png)

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2313237/19344129/ec6aea96-9130-11e6-8720-a67b6243a540.png)
### Versions

Windows 10
atom 1.12-Beta1

### Description

Getting error message when trying to save keymap:

Failed to load /Users/tyurins/.atom/keymap.json
Unexpected token :
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Settings -> Keybindings
2. Copy a keybinding (first one in my case)
3. Open keymap.json (from settings page or from Atom menu)
4. Paste and Save

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

No error

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

Error

data.title: Pane .addItem throwing error when trying to add text editor to it
data.body:
### Description

My package is broken because it adds a new text editor to a pane by doing something like `atom.workspace.getActivePane().addItem(atom.workspace.buildTextEditor())` but gets an error: `Uncaught TypeError: Arguments to CompositeDisposable.add must have a .dispose() method`
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Run `atom.workspace.getActivePane().addItem(atom.workspace.buildTextEditor())` in the console
2. Notice there is an error

**Expected behavior:** I would expect a new text editor to be added to the active pane.

**Actual behavior:** Nothing happens except for an error.
### Versions

Atom v1.11.1 - MacOS

data.title: Spacebar broken in beta
data.body:
### Prerequisites

Atom beta
### Description

The space bar is not resolving with key resolver for my package jumpy + vim-mode.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open editor with vim-mode on
2. press the space bar

**Expected behavior:**
The cursor should progress

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
Key resolver says no key press being passed to the package / commands
### Versions

Atom 1.12.0-beta0
Mac OS 10.11.6

I have created an issue with vim-mode as well:
https://github.com/atom/vim-mode/issues/1071
But I believe this is more of an issue with atom core, as the key resolver doesn't show anything for vim-mode nor my package.  Did the key for the keymap change perhaps?

data.title: Save open documents on crash
data.body:
Atom crashes a whole lot. Happens to me at least once every two days. A nice feature that LibreOffice and some other text editors have is that it saves any unsaved open documents either directly or as a temporary file to be reopened on restart. This might save people from losing info on a frequent basis.

One thing that I notice is that when Atom crashes, it's actually the open window that crashes not the entire program. So, this abstraction would be a nice place to put that functionality

data.title: Numpad DELETE not working [v1.12.0-beta0]
data.body:
### Description

Numpad DELETE not working

Updated to newest Atom Beta yesterday, DELETE key doesn't work in Atom anymore, all others on numpad do work (like HOME, END, PG DOWN). 
As far as I can see, newest update made changes to keymaps, but I think point was to improve, not remove features. 

**Expected behavior:** DELETE to work

**Actual behavior:** Nothing happens
### Versions

apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

data.title: Fullscreen window opens new window on top of parent
data.body: Atom: 1.12.0-beta0 & 1.11.1 OS: macOS Sierra I'm not sure if this is an Electron or an Atom issue - I initially posted it on Electron and was ask to repost here and see if it could be reproduced with the latest Electron build. Since upgrading to macOS Sierra, opening new windows while in fullscreen mode will open the new window on top of the current fullscreened window. This didn't use to happen and I assume was something to do with how macOS have changed their window management API to allow tabs in apps. Here's a screenshot which will hopefully make more sense: Steps to reproduce: 1: open Atom 2: fullscreen application with the green button on the menu bar 3: open new window with cmd-shift-n or File > New Window

data.title: Remember previous window state for multiple fullscreen windows
data.body: Hi, I use Atom for developing multiple micro services so will have at least 3 projects open at a time - which I usually keep in fullscreen mode on macOS. When I cmd-q and quit Atom, then reopen Atom, all the previous windows will be opened but only one of them will be in full screen and the rest will be dumped onto the main desktop. Here's two images of before and after quitting and reopening Atom. Is this something that is possible to implement? If I can be pointed in the right direction I would be happy to see if I can scratch my own itch and submit a pull request. Bonus points: remembering the order of the windows - don't know if that's posible. Thanks

data.title: If Atom is open but no window is open, the Apple taskbar options do not work
data.body:
Hello,

When Atom is running but I do not have a window open, the options in the top Apple task-bar (New Window, New File, Open...etc) do not work.

As a temporary solution, I have to click on the Atom icon in the dock to open a window before any of those options work. This issue is on multiple computers which leads me to believe it is not a local issue.

Kind regards

data.title: Update atom.desktop.in
data.body:
Hi,

In this pull I am editing the `Categories` and `MimeType` fields, for these reasons respectively:
- Deleted the GNOME category as, as that's for GNOME core apps, which Atom is not.
- MimeType should include all default (i.e., with the default bundled packages) supported file types for the editor. Most importantly, it would be delightful if one could open up project folders with Atom using your file manager's context menu. 

Thanks for your time,
Brenton

I'm using macOS 10.11.6
In beta

```
Atom    : 1.12.0-beta0
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0
```

`space` key is just ignored my keymap.cson, 

keymap.cson to reproduce

```
'atom-text-editor':
  'space': 'core:move-right'
  'i': 'core:move-right'
```

`i` moves cursor to right, but `space` just insert single '` `'(space).
keybinding-resolver say nothing against my`space` stroke.

Stable atom have no issue.

My npm version is 3.10.7 ( know that 3.10.8 is out, but I have 3.10.7 installed because 3.10.8 causes build errors with Visual Studio Code) and my Node.js version is 6.7.0 on both my Linux workstations (i.e., my Ubuntu 16.04 install and my Arch Linux install are both using the same versions of npm and Node.js). If you are wondering why `~/Documents/CodeLite/CPP-Math-Projects/` appears in this build error, well I don't know but I have set some custom environment variables namely:

``` bash

CC=/home/fusion809/Documents/CodeLite/CPP-Math-Projects
CFE=/home/fusion809/Documents/CodeLite/CPP-Math-Projects/Simple-Pendulum
CFA=/home/fusion809/Documents/CodeLite/CPP-Math-Projects/Simple-Pendulum-Adjusted
CSP=/home/fusion809/Documents/CodeLite/C-Math-Projects
```

Thanks for your time,
Brenton

data.title: [FIXABLE] Atom's CPU usage increases steadily when scrolling
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

May be related to #10987.

On Win10, when scrolling in some smooth scrolling containers, such as in the settings, Atom's CPU usage steadily rises.
### Steps to Reproduce

You really need a mouse with a stepped scrollwheel for this, and it will hurt your finger a bit…
1. Open Task Manager and for best results, snap Atom to one side and Task Manager to the other.
2. Open the Install tab of the settings
3. Scroll back and forth, quickly without stopping. 
4. Watch the CPU usage in the Atom subprocesses in Task Manager.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

CPU usage remains steady. About 25% CPU usage max.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

Atom's CPU usage begins to rise to about 50% (for me). Compared to 0% idle.
### Potential Fix

In the element inspector, pressing **⋮** > More tools > Rendering settings and checking "Show scrolling perf issues" will highlight the scroll container that settings is in as "Repaints on scroll".

I Googled it and found this fix: In any container where `overflow: auto` or `overflow: scroll` is (such as `.settings-view .panels .panels-item`, this container), also place `will-change: transform;`. This tells it to use the compositor. 

Adding this in the element inspector makes it so it only rises to ~15%. Hell of a lot better.

However, if we do that, text rendering gets a bit thicker, so I found it works to decrease the `font-weight` by 100. So `font-weight: normal;` becomes `font-weight: 300`, and `font-weight: bold;` becomes `font-weight: 600;` 

I don't have the time to clone Atom, find and fix each and every occurrence of the overflow container at the moment.
### Versions

```
C:\> atom --version

Atom    : 1.11.1  
Electron: 0.37.8  
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75  
Node    : 5.10.0  
```

Win10 Home Anniversary (x86)
Dell Precision T3400
Core 2 Duo E7400 @ 2.8GHz
ATI FirePro V4800
1920x1080 LCD @ 60Hz via VGA
4GB RAM (3.25 usable)

data.title: Shortcut for close file (macOS 10.12)
data.body:
### Prerequisites

- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Can't close new file without saving
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create new file
2. Write something
3. Cmd + W
4. Cmd + D

[Video](https://monosnap.com/file/QV7psgRz1Fb5Z6PhMzmRZXB4ryGCXw)

**Expected behavior:** Close file

**Actual behavior:** Nothing
### Versions

Atom    : 1.11.0
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

data.title: Fixes #11848 Moving line up without line ending
data.body:
## Bug

Fixes the bug described in issue #11848

![move-line-up-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5964236/19289643/31871060-9068-11e6-89ad-055e0d2bb5d5.gif)
## Fix

From what I explored it looks like a previous dev has tried to fix this bug. Although because rows are 0 indexed, to select the penultimate row for the range it requires using `-2`. 

I wonder whether it's worth rewriting the line:

``` coffeescript
lines += '\n' unless lines[lines.length - 1] is '\n'
```

I've attempted to add a valid test. Suggestions to improve or better represent the test welcome 😸 

![move-line-up-fix](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5964236/19289650/3aee8e58-9068-11e6-8fc9-9066c1306ebb.gif)

data.title: atom fails to open a window in debian 9-prerelease with lxdm/openbox/lxde
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [?] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

atom fails to open a window in debian 9-prerelease with lxdm/openbox/lxde.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. install atom from the .deb using gdebi
2. try to start atom.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
atom starts up normally.
**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
atom never opens a window, hangs indefinitely, strace reveals it's doing an infinite loop of nanosleep({0, 2000001}, NULL); 
and no startup parameters change this (it's the same in --version --safe --profile-startup, it doesn't make any difference.)
### Versions

apm --version relevals:
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12+
git 2.9.3

contradictory to documentation, i can NOT check the atom version by invoking atom --version, because it enters the same nanosleep() loop as a normal invocation, but it should be the latest released version .deb of 2016-10-10 (ISO8601 format) from atom.io 

i'm running debian 9 testing, with lxdm / openbox / lxde, amd64, inside VMWare,

uname -a: 
Linux debian9clean 4.7.0-1-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 4.7.5-1 (2016-09-26) x86_64 GNU/Linux

data.title: Exclude beginner issues from help wanted issues
data.body:
Looking at https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#your-first-code-contribution I suggest the following changes:
1. Exclude beginner label from the help wanted search link. Help wanted without beginner currently is supposed to be more involved issues and we want to search for these exclusively.
2. Sort by reactions rather than comments. We don't want to encourage +1 comments.

Currently fixes 1. I am unsure how to fix 2 since we would have to search by multiple reactions combined.

/cc: @lee-dohm @iolsen

data.title: Executing pane:close will ask to save changes of TextEditors twice
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

If you execute `pane:close` the dialog asking you to save appears twice when you press the `Dont Save` button. This does not happen with `core:close` command in combination with the `Close Empty Panes` configuration option.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom in safe mode.
1. Ensure you only have one pane, this bug does not reproduce when closing a split pane.
1. Open a new untitled tab (Or any tab it is not limited to untitled tabs).
1. Make any modifications to the tab.
1. Run `pane:close` from the `command-palette`, this doesn't reproduce when the pane is closed using the `Remove Empty Panes` option.
1. In the dialog that appears press `Don't Save`.

![pane close dialog](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1058982/19284692/4c058c8a-8ff7-11e6-936f-60b2b748e0c4.gif)

**Expected behavior:** Pane to close.

**Actual behavior:** Dialog asking to save appears once again.
### Versions
###### atom --version

```
Atom    : 1.12.0-beta0
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0
```
###### apm --version

```
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.11
git 2.10.1.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```
